page.title: 18HISTORY OF THE VILLAGES
page.content: The village of Whixley is mentioned in Domesday as Qwixley and traces of a Saxon church were found at the Victorian restoration of the l2th C. church. It was burned by the Scots in the l4th C. The Bank family held the manor before the Tancreds who were the last lords of the manor. The Roman road from Newton Kyme to Aldbrough goes through the village and it is said that the cobbles used in many of the old houses were from that Roman 'street'. There was no church at Green Hammerton until Victorian times when the Vicar of Whixley Rev. Valentine had a small Gothic stone building made for the people of the village in l876. The Bay Horse and many houses on the Green are l8th C. and it was undoubtedly a coaching place on the North route from York. The Manor,now gone,once was owned by the Farrers.
